text:
The **economy of Palestine** refers to the economic activity of Palestine.
Palestine receives substantial financial aid from various international
donors, including governments and international organizations. In 2020, the
inflation rate was -0.7% and the unemployment rate was 25.9%. While exports
were recorded at US$1 billion, with an import value of US$6 billion.
Contributors to the national economy is service sector (47%), wholesale and
repair (19%), manufacturing (12%), agriculture (7%), finance and banking (3%),
construction (5%), information technology (5%) and transportation sector (2%).

This aid is crucial for supporting the Palestinian Authority and funding
public services and development projects. Palestinians working abroad send
money back to their families in Palestine. These remittances provide a
significant source of income for many households. Palestinian economy relies
heavily on donations and international aid from various sources, including
UNRWA, Qatar, Turkey, the European Union, and non-governmental organizations.
Contribution to the economy also comes from remittances sent by the
Palestinian diaspora. Gazans experience additional difficulties as they are
subjected to a siege, with Israel controlling the movement of people and goods
in and out of Gaza. Nonetheless, there are limited business opportunities
available in Gaza. Contrastingly, the West Bank provides Palestinians with
more diverse opportunities. Some individuals own businesses in tourism-driven
areas such as Bethlehem and Jerusalem, as tourism serves as a significant
source of income. Others engage in various types of enterprises in cities like
Ramallah and Hebron, ranging from trading to construction and IT services.
Furthermore, approximately 100,000 Palestinians find employment in Israeli
companies as low-cost labor, earning significantly less than the average
Israeli worker.

While trade is restricted due to political factors, Palestine does engage in
some export activities. Palestinian products, such as agricultural goods and
traditional crafts, are exported to regional and international markets.
Despite the challenges, tourism plays a role in the Palestinian economy. The
historical and cultural significance of places like Bethlehem and Jerusalem
draws tourists. Agriculture remains a crucial sector, with Palestinians
cultivating crops, producing olive oil, and raising livestock. Some
Palestinians work in various service industries, including education,
healthcare, and technology. Palestine hosts numerous international non-
governmental organizations (NGOs) and humanitarian agencies, which contribute
to the local economy and provide employment.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Palestine encompasses all economic activities within the Palestinian territories.

• Palestine receives substantial financial aid from various international donors, including governments and international organizations, which is vital for supporting the Palestinian Authority and funding public services and development projects.
• In 2020, Palestine experienced an inflation rate of -0.7% and an unemployment rate of 25.9%.
• The total value of exports in 2020 was recorded at US$1 billion, while imports amounted to US$6 billion.

• The national economy is primarily composed of the service sector (47%), followed by wholesale and repair (19%), manufacturing (12%), agriculture (7%), finance and banking (3%), construction (5%), information technology (5%), and transportation (2%).
• Remittances sent by Palestinians working abroad constitute a significant source of income for many households and contribute notably to the Palestinian economy.

• International aid and donations come from multiple sources, including the United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA), Qatar, Turkey, the European Union, and various non-governmental organizations (NGOs).
• The Palestinian economy heavily depends on these remittances and international aid for financial stability and development.
• The Gaza Strip faces additional economic challenges due to an Israeli-imposed siege controlling the movement of people and goods, severely limiting business opportunities.

• In contrast, the West Bank offers more diverse economic opportunities, with some Palestinians owning businesses in tourism-centric areas such as Bethlehem and Jerusalem, where tourism is a significant income source.
• Other economic activities in West Bank cities like Ramallah and Hebron include trading, construction, and information technology services.
• Approximately 100,000 Palestinians are employed by Israeli companies as low-cost labor, earning wages significantly lower than the average Israeli worker.
• Despite political restrictions on trade, Palestine engages in export activities, including agricultural products and traditional crafts, which are sold in regional and international markets.
• Tourism contributes to the Palestinian economy by attracting visitors to historically and culturally significant sites such as Bethlehem and Jerusalem.
• Agriculture remains a vital sector, with Palestinians cultivating crops, producing olive oil, and raising livestock.
• Many Palestinians are employed in service industries such as education, healthcare, and technology.
• Numerous international NGOs and humanitarian agencies operate in Palestine, contributing to the local economy and providing employment opportunities.

text:
GDP per capita in the Palestinian territories rose by 7% per year from 1968 to
1980 but slowed during the 1980s. Between 1970 and 1991 life expectancy rose
from 56 to 66 years, infant mortality per 1,000 fell from 95 to 42, households
with electricity rose from 30% to 85%, households with safe water rose from
15% to 90%, households with a refrigerator rose from 11% to 85%, and
households with a washing machine rose from 23% in 1980 to 61% in 1991.

Economic conditions in the West Bank and Gaza Strip, where economic activity
was governed by the Paris Economic Protocol of April 1994 between Israel and
the Palestinian Authority, deteriorated in the early 1990s. Real per capita
GDP for the West Bank and Gaza Strip (WBGS) declined 36.1% between 1992 and
1996 owing to the combined effect of falling aggregate incomes and robust
population growth. The downturn in economic activity was due to Israeli
closure policies in response to terrorist attacks in Israel, which disrupted
previously established labor and commodity market relationships. The most
serious effect was the emergence of chronic unemployment. Average unemployment
rates in the 1980s were generally under 5%; while by the mid-1990s it had
risen to over 20%. After 1997, Israel's use of comprehensive closures
decreased and new policies were implemented. In October 1999, Israel permitted
the opening of a safe passage between the West Bank and the Gaza Strip in
accordance with the 1995 Interim Agreement. These changes in the conduct of
economic activity fueled a moderate economic recovery in 1998–99.

As a result of the Israeli blockade, 85% of factories were shut or operated at
less than 20% capacity. It is estimated that Israeli businesses lost $2
million a day from the closure while Gaza lost approximately $1 million a day.
The World Bank estimated the nominal GDP of the territories at US$4,007,000
and of Israel at US$161,822,000. Per capita these numbers are respectively
US$1,036 and US$22,563 per year.
openai_summarised_points: • From 1968 to 1980, GDP per capita in the Palestinian territories increased at an annual rate of 7%, though this growth rate slowed during the 1980s.

• Between 1970 and 1991, significant improvements in social indicators were recorded in the Palestinian territories: life expectancy rose from 56 to 66 years, and infant mortality per 1,000 live births declined from 95 to 42.

• Household access to basic amenities improved markedly from 1970 to 1991: electricity availability increased from 30% to 85%, access to safe water rose from 15% to 90%, ownership of refrigerators grew from 11% to 85%, and ownership of washing machines increased from 23% in 1980 to 61% in 1991.
• Economic activity in the West Bank and Gaza Strip (WBGS) was regulated under the Paris Economic Protocol of April 1994, an agreement between Israel and the Palestinian Authority.

• The WBGS experienced economic deterioration in the early 1990s, with real per capita GDP declining by 36.1% between 1992 and 1996 due to falling aggregate incomes combined with rapid population growth.

• The economic downturn was primarily caused by Israeli closure policies implemented in response to terrorist attacks in Israel, which disrupted established labor and commodity market linkages between Israel and the Palestinian territories.

• A critical consequence of these disruptions was the rise of chronic unemployment in the WBGS; average unemployment rates, which had been below 5% during the 1980s, surged to over 20% by the mid-1990s.
• After 1997, Israel reduced the use of comprehensive closures and introduced new policies to ease restrictions.

• In October 1999, Israel authorized the opening of a safe passage between the West Bank and Gaza Strip, in accordance with the 1995 Interim Agreement, facilitating improved movement and economic activity.
• These policy changes contributed to a moderate economic recovery in the WBGS during 1998–1999.
• Due to the Israeli blockade, 85% of factories in the Palestinian territories were either shut down or operated at less than 20% of their capacity.
• The economic impact of closures was substantial: Israeli businesses reportedly lost approximately $2 million per day, while Gaza's economy lost about $1 million per day.
• According to World Bank estimates, the nominal GDP of the Palestinian territories was US$4,007,000, compared to Israel’s nominal GDP of US$161,822,000.
• On a per capita basis, the nominal GDP was US$1,036 per year in the Palestinian territories and US$22,563 per year in Israel.

text:
During the worldwide recession of the 1930s, Palestine, including its Arab
population, suffered severe economic hardships. The global economic downturn
had an impact on the region, leading to economic decline and increased
unemployment. However, by the end of World War II, Palestine had experienced a
significant level of prosperity and was considered one of the most advanced
countries in the Middle East in terms of economic development. This prosperity
was attributed to several factors. Firstly, during the war, Palestine served
as a center of British communications, which brought numerous benefits to the
economy. The region benefited from contracts in transport, military
construction, and supply, as well as the establishment of a large oil refinery
in Haifa. These activities created employment opportunities and stimulated
economic growth. Additionally, agricultural exports, particularly citrus
fruit, saw a marked increase during this period. The disruption of supplies
from other parts of the Mediterranean due to the war, especially the actions
of the Germans, created a higher demand for Palestinian citrus products. This
presented an opportunity for both Arab and Jewish citrus producers to take
advantage of the increased demand and contribute to the economic growth.
Although many contracts awarded by the British Mandatory authorities during
this period went to the new Jewish immigrants, Arab Palestinians also
benefited from the economic opportunities. Arab Palestinians were able to
provide cheaper labor, which made them attractive for employment in various
sectors. They found employment in the railroads, large military construction
projects, and government departments like the police.

During the war, Palestine experienced a period of economic prosperity, which
coincided with new forms of investment and trade that connected the region and
its entrepreneurs to the global market. The profits generated during this time
were invested in various financial instruments such as shares, government
bonds, and commodity stocks. After the dispersion of people in 1948, some
individuals were able to recover a portion of their wealth through these
investments. The passage suggests that data collected by the Mandatory
government provides estimates of the wealth held in Palestine during that
period. According to the data, the total ownership of capital in the country
in 1945 amounted to 281 million Palestinian pounds. Of this total,
approximately 47 percent (132.6 million pounds) was owned by the Arab
community. The majority of this wealth (74.8 million pounds) was invested in
rural landholdings that could not be transferred abroad. However, there were
other assets, such as investments in foreign stocks and shares, which were in
a form that could be recovered by those who went into exile. These foreign
liquid assets amounted to just over 39 million pounds. Additionally, Arab
banks in Palestine held 7 million pounds in bank deposits, and another 3
million pounds were deposited in the Ottoman Bank or the local branch of
Barclays Bank, some of which was recovered through international litigation in
the early 1950s.

A significant portion of the bank deposits held in Arab banks in Palestine,
amounting to approximately 10 million pounds, was transferred to Jordan. This
transfer occurred as a result of the mass displacement of Palestinians during
the 1948-1949 Arab-Israeli war, with many seeking refuge in Jordan.
Furthermore, it mentions that at least 1.5 million pounds in the form of
banknotes was brought into the country prior to the abolition of the
Palestinian currency. This indicates that individuals who left Palestine took
physical banknotes with them as they sought refuge or migrated to other
regions. At least 1.5 million pounds in the form of banknotes was transferred
to Syria. Smaller amounts being sent to Egypt and Iraq. These transfers
suggest that some individuals who left Palestine took physical banknotes with
them to these countries.
openai_summarised_points: • During the worldwide recession of the 1930s, Palestine, including its Arab population, experienced severe economic hardships characterized by economic decline and increased unemployment due to the global economic downturn.
• By the end of World War II, Palestine had achieved a significant level of prosperity and was regarded as one of the most economically advanced countries in the Middle East.

• The wartime prosperity in Palestine was largely attributed to its role as a center of British communications, which brought economic benefits through contracts in transport, military construction, and supply sectors.
• The establishment of a large oil refinery in Haifa during World War II contributed to employment creation and stimulated economic growth in the region.

• Agricultural exports, particularly citrus fruit, experienced a marked increase during the war due to disrupted supplies from other Mediterranean regions caused by German military actions, leading to higher demand for Palestinian citrus products.
• Both Arab and Jewish citrus producers capitalized on the increased demand for citrus exports, thereby contributing to Palestine’s economic growth during this period.

• Although many British Mandatory government contracts were awarded to new Jewish immigrants, Arab Palestinians also benefited economically by providing cheaper labor, securing employment in railroads, military construction projects, and government departments such as the police.

• The wartime economic prosperity coincided with new forms of investment and trade that connected Palestinian entrepreneurs to the global market, with profits invested in shares, government bonds, and commodity stocks.
• Following the 1948 dispersion of people, some individuals were able to recover portions of their wealth through these financial investments.
• Data collected by the British Mandatory government estimated that total capital ownership in Palestine in 1945 was 281 million Palestinian pounds.
• Of the total capital ownership in 1945, approximately 47 percent (132.6 million Palestinian pounds) was owned by the Arab community.
• The majority of Arab-owned wealth, amounting to 74.8 million Palestinian pounds, was invested in rural landholdings, which were non-transferable abroad.
• Arab Palestinians also held other assets in recoverable forms such as foreign stocks and shares, amounting to just over 39 million Palestinian pounds, which could be reclaimed by exiles.

• Arab banks in Palestine held 7 million Palestinian pounds in bank deposits, with an additional 3 million pounds deposited in the Ottoman Bank or the local branch of Barclays Bank; some of these funds were recovered through international litigation in the early 1950s.

• Approximately 10 million Palestinian pounds in bank deposits held by Arab banks were transferred to Jordan as a result of the mass displacement of Palestinians during the 1948-1949 Arab-Israeli war, with many refugees seeking shelter in Jordan.

• At least 1.5 million Palestinian pounds in the form of physical banknotes were brought into Palestine prior to the abolition of the Palestinian currency, indicating that individuals who left Palestine took physical cash with them.

• Similar transfers of physical banknotes occurred to Syria (at least 1.5 million pounds), with smaller amounts sent to Egypt and Iraq, reflecting the movement of Palestinian refugees and migrants carrying cash assets to these countries.

text:
During the 1970s and subsequent years, a considerable number of Palestinians
sought employment opportunities in Israel. This labor integration provided
income and remittances, which had positive effects on the Palestinian economy.
Palestinian workers played a significant role in various sectors of the
Israeli economy, such as construction, agriculture, and manufacturing. While
there were some economic benefits from labor integration, the overall economic
disparities between Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories persisted.
Palestinians faced limited access to resources, markets, and capital, which
hindered their economic development.

Integration into the Israeli labor market provided Palestinians with access to
job opportunities that were not readily available in the occupied territories.
Palestinians found employment in various sectors, including construction,
agriculture, manufacturing, and services. This helped alleviate unemployment
and provided a source of income for Palestinian workers and their families.
The General Federation of Trade Unions, representing Palestinian workers, was
founded to advocate for their rights and interests.

Palestinian exports peaked in 1981 followed by a decline through the 1990s. In
the same time period imports nearly doubled, increasing a trade deficit of 35%
of GDP in 1981 to a deficit of 45% of GDP in 1996. The first Intifada, a
Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation, which took place from 1987 to
1993, had a profound impact on the Palestinian economy. The Intifada led to
widespread disruptions, closures, and restrictions imposed by Israel, which
greatly affected economic activities and livelihoods. In 1991, the invasion of
Kuwait and resulting Gulf War affected the Palestinian economy. The Madrid
Conference, held that same year, improved economic collaboration between the
Arab countries and Israel.

The Oslo Accords, signed in the 1990s, led to the establishment of the
Palestinian Authority (PA) and limited self-governance in parts of the West
Bank and Gaza. The PA took on responsibilities in areas such as trade,
investment, and public services. However, the overall impact on the
Palestinian economy was mixed, as the peace process faced setbacks and the
Israeli occupation persisted. In 1994, The Paris Protocol was signed,
outlining economic relations between Israel and the PA, including provisions
for labor movement and employment. Next year, the Israeli government imposed
restrictions on the movement of Palestinian workers within Israel due to
security concerns. The PA assumed control over some economic sectors,
including tourism, trade, and investment by 1995. Until 1999 the Palestinian
economy experienced a period of relative growth and stability with increased
international aid and improved economic indicators.

For 30 years, Israel permitted thousands of Palestinians to enter the country
each day to work in construction, agriculture and other blue-collar jobs.
During this period, the Palestinian economy was significantly greater than the
majority of Arab states. Until the mid-1990s, up to 150,000 people—about a
fifth of the Palestinian labor force—entered Israel each day. After
Palestinians unleashed a wave of suicide bombings, the idea of separation from
the Palestinians took root in Israel. Israel found itself starved for labor,
and gradually replaced most of the Palestinians with migrants from Thailand,
Romania and elsewhere.
openai_summarised_points: • During the 1970s and subsequent years, a significant number of Palestinians sought employment opportunities in Israel, integrating into its labor market and providing income and remittances that positively influenced the Palestinian economy.

• Palestinian workers contributed substantially to various sectors of the Israeli economy, including construction, agriculture, and manufacturing, although economic disparities between Israel and the occupied Palestinian territories remained pronounced.
• Despite some economic benefits from labor integration, Palestinians faced restricted access to essential resources, markets, and capital, which impeded their broader economic development.

• Employment opportunities in Israel spanned multiple sectors such as construction, agriculture, manufacturing, and services, helping to reduce unemployment among Palestinians and providing vital income for workers and their families.
• The General Federation of Trade Unions was established to represent Palestinian workers and advocate for their rights and interests within this labor context.

• Palestinian exports reached their peak in 1981 but subsequently declined throughout the 1990s, while imports nearly doubled during the same period, causing the trade deficit to widen from 35% of GDP in 1981 to 45% of GDP in 1996.

• The First Intifada (1987–1993), a Palestinian uprising against Israeli occupation, severely disrupted the Palestinian economy through widespread closures and Israeli-imposed restrictions, adversely affecting economic activities and livelihoods.

• The 1991 invasion of Kuwait and the ensuing Gulf War had a notable impact on the Palestinian economy, while the Madrid Conference held that year fostered improved economic collaboration between Arab countries and Israel.

• The Oslo Accords of the 1990s resulted in the creation of the Palestinian Authority (PA) and granted limited self-governance in parts of the West Bank and Gaza, with the PA assuming responsibilities in trade, investment, and public services.
• Despite these developments, the overall economic impact of the Oslo Accords was mixed due to ongoing setbacks in the peace process and the continued Israeli occupation.
• In 1994, the Paris Protocol was signed, establishing the framework for economic relations between Israel and the PA, including regulations on labor movement and employment.

• In 1995, the Israeli government imposed restrictions on the movement of Palestinian workers within Israel, citing security concerns, while the PA gained control over certain economic sectors such as tourism, trade, and investment.
• Between 1995 and 1999, the Palestinian economy experienced a period of relative growth and stability, supported by increased international aid and improved economic indicators.

• For approximately 30 years, Israel allowed thousands of Palestinians to enter daily for work in construction, agriculture, and other blue-collar jobs, during which time the Palestinian economy was significantly larger than that of most Arab states.
• Until the mid-1990s, up to 150,000 Palestinians—about 20% of the Palestinian labor force—entered Israel each day for employment.

• Following a wave of Palestinian suicide bombings, Israeli public opinion shifted towards separation from Palestinians, leading Israel to gradually replace Palestinian laborers with migrant workers from countries such as Thailand and Romania due to labor shortages.

text:
In 2005, the PNA Ministry of Finance cited the Israeli West Bank barrier,
whose construction began in the second half of 2002, as one reason for the
depressed Palestinian economic activity. Real GDP growth in the West Bank
declined substantially in 2000, 2001, and 2002, and increased modestly in 2003
and 2004. The World Bank attributed the modest economic growth since 2003 to
"diminished levels of violence, fewer curfews, and more predictable (albeit
still intense) closures, as well as adaptation by Palestinian business to the
contours of a constrained West Bank economy". Under a "disengagement scenario"
the Bank predicted a real growth rate of −0.2% in 2006 and −0.6% in 2007.

In the wake of Israel's unilateral disengagement from Gaza, there were
shortages of bread and basic supplies due to closure of the al Mentar/Karni
border-crossing into Israel. Israel's offer to open other crossings was turned
down by the Hamas-run Palestinian authority.

Following the January 2006 legislative elections, decisively won by Hamas, the
Quartet (apart from Russia) cut all funds to the Palestinian Authority led by
prime minister Ismail Haniyah (Hamas). The PA had a monthly cash deficit of
$60 million-$70 million after it received $50 million – $55 million a month
from Israel in taxes and customs duties collected by Israeli officials at the
borders. After the elections, the Palestinian stock market fell about 20%, and
the PA exhausted its borrowing capacity with local banks. Israel ceased
transferring $55 million in tax receipts to the PA. These funds accounted for
a third of the PA's budget and paid the wages of 160,000 Palestinian civil
servants (among them 60,000 security and police officers). The United States
and the European Union halted direct aid to the PA, while the US imposed a
financial blockade on PA's banks, impeding the transfer of some of the Arab
League's funds (e.g. Saudi Arabia and Qatar). In May 2006, hundreds of
Palestinians demonstrated in Gaza and the West Bank demanding payment of their
wages. Tension between Hamas and Fatah rose as a result of this "economic
squeeze" on the PA.

In 2009, the Israeli military removed its checkpoint at the entrance of Jenin
in a series of reductions in security measures. In September 2012, EU
activists stated that the Palestinian economy "lost access to 40% of the West
Bank, 82% of its groundwater and more than two-thirds of its grazing land" due
to the occupation and settlement construction.

The first planned Palestinian city named Rawabi is under construction north of
Ramallah, with the help of funds from Qatar. In 2013, commercial trade between
Israel and the Palestinian territories was valued at US$20 billion annually.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2005, the Palestinian National Authority (PNA) Ministry of Finance identified the Israeli West Bank barrier, whose construction began in the latter half of 2002, as a significant factor contributing to depressed Palestinian economic activity.
• Real GDP growth in the West Bank experienced a substantial decline during the years 2000, 2001, and 2002, followed by modest increases in 2003 and 2004.

• The World Bank attributed the modest economic growth since 2003 to factors including diminished levels of violence, fewer curfews, more predictable (though still intense) closures, and Palestinian businesses adapting to the constraints of the West Bank economy.
• Under a "disengagement scenario," the World Bank projected a real growth rate of −0.2% in 2006 and −0.6% in 2007 for the Palestinian economy.
• Following Israel's unilateral disengagement from Gaza, shortages of bread and basic supplies occurred due to the closure of the al Mentar/Karni border crossing into Israel.
• Israel offered to open alternative border crossings after the Gaza disengagement, but the Hamas-led Palestinian Authority declined these offers.

• After the January 2006 legislative elections, which Hamas decisively won, the Quartet (comprising the United States, European Union, United Nations, and Russia, though Russia did not participate in the sanctions) cut all funds to the Palestinian Authority led by Prime Minister Ismail Haniyah of Hamas.

• The Palestinian Authority faced a monthly cash deficit of $60 million to $70 million, despite receiving $50 million to $55 million monthly from Israel in taxes and customs duties collected at the borders.
• Post-election, the Palestinian stock market declined by approximately 20%, and the Palestinian Authority exhausted its borrowing capacity with local banks.

• Israel ceased transferring $55 million in tax receipts to the Palestinian Authority, funds which represented one-third of the PA's budget and financed the salaries of 160,000 Palestinian civil servants, including 60,000 security and police officers.

• The United States and the European Union halted direct aid to the Palestinian Authority, and the United States imposed a financial blockade on PA banks, obstructing the transfer of some funds from Arab League countries such as Saudi Arabia and Qatar.
• In May 2006, hundreds of Palestinians in Gaza and the West Bank protested to demand payment of their wages amid the financial crisis.
• The economic squeeze on the Palestinian Authority intensified tensions between Hamas and Fatah factions.
• In 2009, the Israeli military removed its checkpoint at the entrance of Jenin as part of a series of security measure reductions.

• In September 2012, European Union activists reported that the Palestinian economy had lost access to 40% of the West Bank territory, 82% of its groundwater resources, and more than two-thirds of its grazing land due to Israeli occupation and settlement construction.
• The first planned Palestinian city, Rawabi, was under construction north of Ramallah with financial assistance from Qatar.
• In 2013, commercial trade between Israel and the Palestinian territories was valued at approximately US$20 billion annually.

text:
Agriculture is a mainstay in the economy. The production of agricultural goods
supports the population's sustenance needs and fuels Palestine's export
economy. According to the Council for European Palestinian Relations, the
agricultural sector formally employs 13.4% of the population and informally
employs 90% of the population. Around 183,000 hectares of land in the
Palestinian territories are cultivated, of which around half is used for olive
production. Olive products earn more in export income than any other
agricultural crop.

Over the past 10 years, unemployment rates in Palestine have increased and the
agricultural sector became the most impoverished sector in Palestine.

Palestinian agriculture suffers from numerous problems, blockades to
exportation of produce and importation of necessary inputs, widespread
confiscation of land for nature reserves as well as military and settler use,
confiscation and destruction of wells, and physical barriers within the West
Bank. Because the root of the conflict is with land, the disputes between
Israel and Palestine are well-manifested in the agriculture of Palestine.
openai_summarised_points: • Agriculture constitutes a fundamental component of the Palestinian economy, providing essential sustenance for the population and serving as a significant contributor to Palestine's export revenues.

• The Council for European Palestinian Relations reports that the agricultural sector formally employs 13.4% of the Palestinian population, while informal employment within the sector reaches as high as 90%.
• Approximately 183,000 hectares of land in the Palestinian territories are under cultivation, with about 50% of this cultivated land dedicated to olive production.
• Olive products represent the highest-earning agricultural export crop for Palestine, generating more export income than any other agricultural commodity.
• Over the last decade, unemployment rates in Palestine have risen, rendering the agricultural sector the most impoverished economic sector within the region.
• Palestinian agriculture faces multiple challenges, including blockades that restrict the export of produce and the import of necessary agricultural inputs.
• There is widespread confiscation of agricultural land, which is repurposed for nature reserves, military use, and settler activities, severely limiting available farming areas.
• The destruction and confiscation of wells further exacerbate water scarcity issues critical to agricultural productivity.
• Physical barriers within the West Bank impede agricultural activities and access to farmland.

• The agricultural difficulties in Palestine are deeply intertwined with the broader Israeli-Palestinian conflict, as disputes over land ownership and control are directly reflected in the challenges faced by Palestinian agriculture.

text:
During the 2000s, a high-tech sector emerged in the Palestinian territories,
supported by its proximity to Israel, and by 2013, 4,500 Palestinians worked
in the IT sector, specializing in software outsourcing (including outsourced
work from Israeli companies), telecommunication development and manufacturing
equipment. The Palestinian IT sector grew from 0.8% of GDP in 2008 to 5% in
2010. The industry has seen a 64% increase in foreign business since 2009. The
majority of Palestinian IT companies are concerted in the city of Ramallah
north of Jerusalem.

Since 2010, Israeli high-tech companies have begun to employ Palestinian
engineers. To date, most of them are outsourced workers, but Mellanox, a
computer hardware firm, plans to hire 15–20 Palestinian engineers as regular
employees. Joint economic cooperation between Israelis and Palestinians
officials has experienced growth over the past years. Starting in 2008, Cisco
Systems began a concerted effort to jump-start the nascent Palestinian IT
sector with a holistic ecosystem approach, encompassing venture capital,
private equity, capacity building and direct outsourcing to Palestinian
companies. The company invested $15 million toward that end and drew in other
major international investors and donors, including Microsoft, HP and Google.
The Palestinian IT sector has since grown from 0.8% of GDP in 2008 to 5% in
2010.

In May 2018, the World Bank published a major report into the Palestinian
technology sector entitled, "Tech startup ecosystem in West Bank and Gaza."
According to the report, as of early 2017, there were 241 active tech start-
ups in Palestinian Territories, which has created a total of 1,247 jobs. The
report also recorded 51 active investors in Palestinian tech companies (around
75 percent angel investors and 25 percent venture capital firms). Among the
major VC firms listed are Sadara Ventures, Ibtikar Fund and Oasis500. Venture
capital firms reported having invested just under US$150 million in over 40
Palestinian tech companies by 2017. The report also recorded 20 start-up
accelerator programs, 19 of which are in the West Bank, and one, Gaza Sky
Geeks, in the Gaza Strip. Today Palestine is known as the "Silicon Valley of
the NGOs".[_citation needed_]
openai_summarised_points: • During the 2000s, a high-tech sector emerged in the Palestinian territories, benefiting from its proximity to Israel and focusing on software outsourcing, telecommunication development, and manufacturing equipment.
• By 2013, approximately 4,500 Palestinians were employed in the IT sector, with many specializing in outsourced work from Israeli companies.
• The Palestinian IT sector’s contribution to GDP increased significantly from 0.8% in 2008 to 5% in 2010.
• Since 2009, the Palestinian IT industry experienced a 64% increase in foreign business.
• The majority of Palestinian IT companies are concentrated in the city of Ramallah, located north of Jerusalem.
• From 2010 onwards, Israeli high-tech companies began employing Palestinian engineers, primarily as outsourced workers.
• Mellanox, a computer hardware firm, planned to hire 15–20 Palestinian engineers as regular employees, marking a shift from outsourcing to direct employment.
• Joint economic cooperation between Israeli and Palestinian officials has grown in recent years, fostering collaboration in the high-tech sector.

• Starting in 2008, Cisco Systems initiated a comprehensive effort to develop the Palestinian IT sector using a holistic ecosystem approach that included venture capital, private equity, capacity building, and direct outsourcing to Palestinian companies.
• Cisco Systems invested $15 million in this initiative and attracted other major international investors and donors such as Microsoft, HP, and Google.
• The Palestinian IT sector’s GDP contribution grew from 0.8% in 2008 to 5% in 2010, partly due to these investments and collaborations.
• In May 2018, the World Bank published a report titled "Tech startup ecosystem in West Bank and Gaza," analyzing the Palestinian technology sector.
• According to the World Bank report, as of early 2017, there were 241 active tech start-ups in the Palestinian Territories, creating a total of 1,247 jobs.
• The report identified 51 active investors in Palestinian tech companies, with approximately 75% being angel investors and 25% venture capital firms.
• Major venture capital firms investing in Palestinian tech companies include Sadara Ventures, Ibtikar Fund, and Oasis500.
• By 2017, venture capital firms had invested just under US$150 million in over 40 Palestinian tech companies.
• The report documented 20 start-up accelerator programs, with 19 located in the West Bank and one, Gaza Sky Geeks, in the Gaza Strip.
• Palestine has earned the nickname "Silicon Valley of the NGOs," reflecting its growing reputation in the tech startup ecosystem.

text:
A wide variety of handicrafts, many of which have been produced by Arabs in
Palestine for hundreds of years, continue to be produced today. Palestinian
handicrafts include embroidery work, pottery-making, soap-making, glass-
making, weaving, and olive-wood and Mother of Pearl carvings, among others.
Some Palestinian cities in the West Bank, particularly Bethlehem, Hebron and
Nablus have gained renown for specializing in the production of a particular
handicraft, with the sale and export of such items forming a key part of each
city's economy.

Stonecutting is a traditional source of income for the Palestinian economy.
The annual average output per worker in the stone industry is higher than in
any other sector. There are 650 stone production outlets in the West Bank, 138
of them in Beit Fajjar. The quarried material is cut into a rich range of
pink, sand, golden, and off-white bricks and tiles known as Jerusalem stone.
openai_summarised_points: • Palestinian handicrafts encompass a wide variety of traditional products that have been produced by Arabs in Palestine for hundreds of years and continue to be made today.
• Key Palestinian handicrafts include embroidery work, pottery-making, soap-making, glass-making, weaving, and carvings made from olive wood and Mother of Pearl.
• Several Palestinian cities in the West Bank are renowned for specializing in particular handicrafts, with Bethlehem, Hebron, and Nablus being notable examples.
• The production, sale, and export of these specialized handicrafts constitute a significant component of the local economies of Bethlehem, Hebron, and Nablus.
• Stonecutting represents a traditional and important source of income within the Palestinian economy.
• The stone industry in Palestine has the highest annual average output per worker compared to any other economic sector.
• There are a total of 650 stone production outlets operating in the West Bank, with 138 of these located specifically in Beit Fajjar.
• The quarried stone material is processed into a diverse range of bricks and tiles characterized by colors such as pink, sand, golden, and off-white, collectively known as Jerusalem stone.

text:
Intercontinental Jacir Palace in Bethlehem

In 2010, 4.6 million people visited the Palestinian territories, compared to
2.6 million in 2009. Of that number, 2.2 million were foreign tourists while
2.7 million were domestic. This number of international visits is misleading,
however, since most tourists come for only a few hours or as part of a day
trip itinerary. In the last quarter of 2012 over 150,000 guests stayed in West
Bank hotels; 40% were European and 9% were from the United States and Canada.
Major travel guides write recently that "the West Bank is not the easiest
place in which to travel but the effort is richly rewarded."

The Palestinian Authority and Israeli tourism ministries have attempted to
work together on tourism in the Palestinian territories in a Joint Committee.
Recent cooperation to share access to foreign tourists has not proven
successful in Palestine for many reasons relating to the occupation. Israel
controls the movement of tourists into the West Bank. Foreign tourism is
presently restricted to East Jerusalem and the West Bank, following the August
2013 indefinite closing of the Rafah crossing located between Egypt and the
Hamas controlled Gaza Strip. There is essentially no tourist flow to Gaza
since 2005 because of the ongoing Israeli military land, air, and sea
blockade.

In 2013 Palestinian Authority Tourism minister Rula Ma'ay'a stated that her
government aims to encourage international visits to Palestine, but the
occupation is the main factor preventing the tourism sector from becoming a
major income source to Palestinians. There are no visa conditions imposed on
foreign nationals other than those imposed by the visa policy of Israel.
Access to Jerusalem and the West Bank is controlled by the Government of
Israel and access to Gaza is controlled by Hamas. Entry to the occupied
Palestinian territories requires only a valid international passport but entry
to Israel may be denied for Palestinians or Arabic visitors. In October 2009,
a new project got underway promoting tourism and travel between the two areas.
New business efforts and tourist attractions have been initiated in Jenin.

A large number of international brands operates their hotels in the
Palestinian territories of both the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. These
include Intercontinental Jacir Palace, Seven Arches Hotel Intercontinental,
Marriott Gaza (later Al-Mashtal) and Millennium Palestine Ramallah Hotel. In
1995, Marriott International proposed to construct a business center-cum-
luxury hotel in Gaza. The project was later changed to another hotel, in the
same city.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2010, the Palestinian territories received 4.6 million visitors, a significant increase from 2.6 million in 2009, with 2.2 million identified as foreign tourists and 2.7 million as domestic visitors.
• The reported number of international visits is somewhat misleading, as most tourists visit for only a few hours or participate in day trip itineraries rather than extended stays.
• During the last quarter of 2012, over 150,000 guests stayed in hotels located in the West Bank, with 40% of these guests originating from Europe and 9% from the United States and Canada.
• Major travel guides have recently noted that while the West Bank is not the easiest place to travel, the effort required is richly rewarded by the experience.

• The Palestinian Authority and Israeli tourism ministries have attempted collaboration through a Joint Committee to promote tourism in the Palestinian territories, but cooperation has been largely unsuccessful due to issues related to the Israeli occupation.

• Israel maintains control over the movement of tourists entering the West Bank, restricting foreign tourism primarily to East Jerusalem and the West Bank following the indefinite closure of the Rafah crossing between Egypt and the Hamas-controlled Gaza Strip in August 2013.
• Since 2005, there has been essentially no tourist flow to Gaza due to the ongoing Israeli military blockade by land, air, and sea.

• In 2013, Palestinian Authority Tourism Minister Rula Ma'ay'a emphasized that while the government aims to encourage international tourism, the Israeli occupation remains the principal obstacle preventing tourism from becoming a major source of income for Palestinians.

• There are no specific visa conditions imposed on foreign nationals entering the Palestinian territories beyond those required by Israeli visa policy; however, access to Jerusalem and the West Bank is controlled by Israel, and access to Gaza is controlled by Hamas.
• Entry to the occupied Palestinian territories requires a valid international passport, but entry to Israel may be denied to Palestinians or Arabic visitors.
• In October 2009, a new project was initiated to promote tourism and travel between the West Bank and Israel, including new business ventures and tourist attractions in Jenin.

• Several international hotel brands operate within the Palestinian territories, including the Intercontinental Jacir Palace and Seven Arches Hotel Intercontinental in Bethlehem, Marriott Gaza (later renamed Al-Mashtal), and the Millennium Palestine Ramallah Hotel.
• In 1995, Marriott International proposed constructing a business center combined with a luxury hotel in Gaza; this project was later modified to focus on a different hotel within the same city.

text:
The presence of oil and gas reserves in Palestine has become a contentious
issue, with some advocates suggesting that these fossil fuel resources are
influencing Israel's attacks on the region. According to a 2019 U.N. report,
it is estimated that over 3 billion barrels of oil exist off the coast and
beneath the occupied lands of Palestine. Additionally, the Levant Basin in the
Mediterranean is believed to hold around 1.7 billion barrels of oil, with
another 1.5 billion barrels estimated to lie beneath the occupied West Bank
area. However, under Israeli occupation, Palestinians are not allowed to drill
for oil and gas or develop their independent energy systems, including solar
energy. Meanwhile, Israel has been actively claiming these resources for
itself, approving licenses for companies to explore for more offshore gas
fields. The Israeli government is also interested in building a pipeline to
export gas to European nations, particularly as Europe seeks alternative
energy providers due to the ongoing conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

Many advocates argue that foreign interests in extracting these resources from
Palestinian lands are contributing to the potential genocide faced by
Palestinians. Throughout history, foreign policy in the Middle East has often
revolved around fossil fuels, and this situation seems no different. The
struggle between Israelis and Palestinians dates back to colonial times, with
tensions and conflicts fueled by the desire for community, safety, and control
of the land. The discovery of oil in the region further complicated the
situation, as world powers sought to secure access to this crucial commodity.
The intertwined history of oil and the creation of modern Middle Eastern
states makes it difficult to separate conflicts in the region from the
influence of oil and gas resources. The presence of billions of barrels of oil
in Palestine, combined with the geopolitical interests of various actors, adds
another layer of complexity to the Israel–Palestine conflict. When it comes to
the presence of oil and gas reserves in Palestine, there is an ongoing
conflict between Israel and Palestine over the ownership and exploitation of
these resources. In 1999, a gas field was discovered about 20 miles off the
coast of Gaza. However, negotiations between Israel and Palestine to divide
these resources were disrupted by the Second Intifada, or Palestinian
uprisings, which began in 2000.

Under international law, the oil and gas resources in Palestine should belong
to the occupied territory and not the occupying power (Israel). However,
Israel has been benefiting from the oil and gas reserves beneath Palestinian
lands and waters. Palestine has been unable to access these resources,
resulting in a loss of billions of dollars of economic potential. Moreover,
there are concerns about the environmental impact of fossil fuel extraction,
and Palestinian activists are pushing for a focus on renewable energy instead.
The international community's complicity in the ongoing Israeli occupation and
the conflict in Gaza is seen by some as intricately tied to capitalist
interests and the pursuit of profit. The history of colonialism and the
extraction of oil resources in the Middle East is seen as part of the wider
context of the Israel-Palestine conflict. While some argue that fossil fuels
have a marginal role in the conflict, others believe that religious ideology,
geopolitical strategies, and access to trading routes play a bigger role.
Overall, the conflict in Palestine and the pursuit of oil and gas resources
have deep historical and geopolitical roots that contribute to the ongoing
tensions in the region.

Palestine holds massive potential reserves of oil and gas. Over 3 billion
barrels (480,000,000 m3) of oil are estimated to exist off the coast and
beneath occupied Palestinian lands. The Levant Basin holds around 1.7 billion
barrels (270,000,000 m3) of oil, with another 1.5 billion barrels (240,000,000
m3) barrels beneath the occupied West Bank area. Around 2 billion barrels
(320,000,000 m3) of oil reserves are believed to exist in shore of the Gaza
Strip. According to a report by the UNCTAD, around 1,250 billion barrels
(1.99×1011 m3) of oil reserves are in the occupied Palestinian territory of
the West Bank, probably the Meged oil field. As per the Palestinian Authority,
80% of this oil field falls under the lands owned by Palestinians.

Masadder, a subsidiary of the Palestine Investment Fund is developing the
oilfield in the West Bank. Block-1 field, which spans an area of 432 square
kilometres (167 sq mi) from northwest Ramallah to Qalqilya in Palestine, has
significant potential for recoverable hydrocarbon resources. It is estimated
to have a P90 (a level of certainty) of 0.03 billion barrels (4,800,000 m3) of
recoverable oil and 6,000,000,000 cubic feet (170,000,000 m3). The estimated
cost for the development of the field is $390 million, and it will be carried
out under a production sharing agreement with the Government of Palestine.
Currently, an initial pre-exploration work program is underway to prepare for
designing an exploration plan for approval, which will precede the full-
fledged development of the field.

Natural gas in Palestine is mostly found in Gaza Strip. Gaza Marine is a
natural gas field, located around 32 kilometres (20 mi) from the coast of the
territory in the Mediterranean shore. It holds gas reserves ranging between 28
billion cubic metres (990 billion cubic feet) to 32 billion cubic metres (1.1
trillion cubic feet). These estimates far exceed the needs of the Palestinian
territories in energy. The gas field was discovered by the British Gas Group
in 1999. Upon the discovery of the gas field, it was lauded by Yasser Arafat
as a "Gift from God". A regional cooperation between the Palestinian
Authority, Israel and Egypt were signed for developing the field and Hamas
also gave approval to the Palestinian Authority. However, since the ongoing
Gaza war, this project have been delayed.
openai_summarised_points: • The presence of oil and gas reserves in Palestine is a contentious issue, with some advocates suggesting these fossil fuel resources influence Israel's attacks on the region.
• A 2019 U.N. report estimates over 3 billion barrels of oil exist off the coast and beneath the occupied lands of Palestine.
• The Levant Basin in the Mediterranean is believed to hold around 1.7 billion barrels of oil, with an additional 1.5 billion barrels estimated beneath the occupied West Bank area.
• Under Israeli occupation, Palestinians are prohibited from drilling for oil and gas or developing independent energy systems, including solar energy.

• Israel has been actively claiming these resources, approving licenses for companies to explore offshore gas fields, and pursuing a pipeline to export gas to European nations amid Europe's search for alternative energy due to the Russia-Ukraine conflict.
• Many advocates argue that foreign interests in extracting Palestinian fossil fuel resources contribute to the potential genocide faced by Palestinians.
• The Middle East's foreign policy has historically revolved around fossil fuels, and the Israel-Palestine conflict is deeply intertwined with the region's oil and gas resources.

• The discovery of oil complicated the Israel-Palestine conflict, as world powers sought access to this crucial commodity, making it difficult to separate regional conflicts from oil and gas influences.
• The ongoing conflict between Israel and Palestine includes disputes over ownership and exploitation of oil and gas reserves.
• In 1999, a gas field was discovered approximately 20 miles off the coast of Gaza, but negotiations to divide these resources were disrupted by the Second Intifada starting in 2000.

• International law stipulates that oil and gas resources in occupied territories belong to those territories, not the occupying power; however, Israel benefits from reserves beneath Palestinian lands and waters.
• Palestine's inability to access these resources results in a loss of billions of dollars in economic potential.
• Environmental concerns about fossil fuel extraction have led Palestinian activists to advocate for a focus on renewable energy.
• Some view the international community’s complicity in the Israeli occupation and Gaza conflict as linked to capitalist interests and profit motives.
• The history of colonialism and oil extraction in the Middle East forms part of the broader context of the Israel-Palestine conflict.
• Opinions vary on the role of fossil fuels in the conflict, with some emphasizing religious ideology, geopolitical strategies, and control of trade routes as more significant factors.
• Palestine holds massive potential reserves of oil and gas, with over 3 billion barrels (480,000,000 m³) estimated off the coast and beneath occupied lands.
• The Levant Basin contains around 1.7 billion barrels (270,000,000 m³) of oil, and approximately 1.5 billion barrels (240,000,000 m³) lie beneath the occupied West Bank.
• Around 2 billion barrels (320,000,000 m³) of oil reserves are believed to exist onshore in the Gaza Strip.
• A UNCTAD report estimates about 1,250 billion barrels (1.99×10¹¹ m³) of oil reserves in the occupied West Bank, likely referring to the Meged oil field.
• According to the Palestinian Authority, 80% of the Meged oil field falls under Palestinian-owned lands.
• Masadder, a subsidiary of the Palestine Investment Fund, is developing the oilfield in the West Bank.
• The Block-1 field spans 432 square kilometers (167 sq mi) from northwest Ramallah to Qalqilya and has significant potential for recoverable hydrocarbons.
• Block-1 is estimated to have a P90 recoverable oil volume of 0.03 billion barrels (4,800,000 m³) and 6 billion cubic feet (170,000,000 m³) of gas.
• The estimated development cost for Block-1 is $390 million, to be conducted under a production sharing agreement with the Government of Palestine.
• An initial pre-exploration work program for Block-1 is underway to prepare an exploration plan for approval before full development.
• Natural gas in Palestine is primarily found in the Gaza Strip, notably in the Gaza Marine gas field located about 32 kilometers (20 miles) off the Mediterranean coast.
• Gaza Marine holds gas reserves estimated between 28 billion cubic meters (990 billion cubic feet) and 32 billion cubic meters (1.1 trillion cubic feet), exceeding Palestinian energy needs.
• The Gaza Marine gas field was discovered by the British Gas Group in 1999.
• Yasser Arafat hailed the discovery as a "Gift from God."
• A regional cooperation agreement for developing Gaza Marine was signed by the Palestinian Authority, Israel, and Egypt, with Hamas also approving the Palestinian Authority’s role.
• The Gaza Marine development project has been delayed due to the ongoing Gaza war.

text:
The World Bank estimated in 2016 that restrictive measures placed by Israel on
telecommunication operators in the West Bank have had a notable negative
impact on the development of the Palestinian telecommunications networks,
which is sustaining losses in the range of $1 billion. These restrictive
measures include the denial to operate in 60% of the West Bank under Israeli
military administration (Area C), limitations on the importation of technology
for ICT companies, requiring Palestinian operators to access international
links via a company with Israeli registration, delaying in the provision of
mobile broadband, the failure to set in place an independent regulator for the
sector in the territories, and Israeli operators who lack appropriate
authorizations who continue to operate in the Palestinian market.
openai_summarised_points: • The World Bank estimated in 2016 that restrictive measures imposed by Israel on telecommunication operators in the West Bank have significantly hindered the development of Palestinian telecommunications networks.
• These restrictions have caused the Palestinian telecommunications sector to sustain financial losses estimated at approximately $1 billion.
• One major restriction is the denial of operation rights in 60% of the West Bank, specifically in Area C, which is under Israeli military administration.
• Palestinian ICT companies face limitations on the importation of technology, restricting their ability to develop and expand telecommunications infrastructure.
• Palestinian operators are required to access international telecommunication links exclusively through companies registered in Israel, limiting their autonomy and increasing operational costs.
• There have been delays in the provision and rollout of mobile broadband services within the Palestinian territories due to these restrictions.
• The establishment of an independent regulatory authority for the telecommunications sector in the Palestinian territories has not been implemented, further impeding sector development.
• Israeli telecommunication operators continue to operate within the Palestinian market without obtaining appropriate authorizations, complicating regulatory oversight and market fairness.

text:
In 2007, the economy in the West Bank improved gradually. Economic growth
reached about 4–5% and unemployment dropped about 3%. Israeli figures
indicated that wages in the West Bank rose more than 20% in 2008 and trade
rose about 35%. Tourism in Bethlehem increased to about twice its previous
levels, and tourism increased by 50% in Jericho. Life expectancy is 73.4,
placing the territories 77th in the world, compared with a life expectancy of
72.5 in Jordan, 71.8 in Turkey, and 80.7 in Israel. Car sales in 2008 were
double those of 2007. The International Monetary Fund report for the West Bank
forecast a 7% growth rate for 2009.

The Bethlehem Small Enterprise Center opened in early 2008. Funded by Germany,
the center has helped to promote computer literacy and marketing skills.

View of Bethlehem

In 2009, efforts continued to build Palestinian local institutions and
governments from the ground up. Much of this work was done by Tony Blair and
US General Keith Dayton. Some analysts saw this as a more substantial way to
lay a groundwork for viable institutions and for local peace. In August 2009,
a state of the art web-based system for tracking goods coming in and out of
the area by Palestinian customs was launched in partnership with the United
Nations Conference on Trade and Development.

In 2009, an economic "boom" began with growth reaching 8 percent, higher than
in Israel or the West. However, with inflation around 9.9% that same year,
real economic growth is actually negative insofar as purchasing power has
decreased. Tourism to Bethlehem, which had doubled to 1 million in 2008, rose
to nearly 1.5 million in 2009. New car imports increased by 44 percent. New
shopping malls opened in Jenin and Nablus. As an outcome of the Palestine
Investment Conference, Palestinian developers are planning to build the first
modern Palestinian city, Rawabi.

Bank of Palestine, Ramallah

In 2010, Ramallah was described as a hub of the economic activity thanks to
improved security within the city, successful battle against corruption and
large consumer base.

In 2011, the Palestinian Planning Minister said that GDP growth was expected
to reach 9%, rising to 10% in 2012 and 12% in 2013.
openai_summarised_points: • In 2007, the West Bank economy showed gradual improvement with economic growth reaching approximately 4–5% and unemployment decreasing by about 3%.
• Israeli data indicated that wages in the West Bank increased by more than 20% in 2008, while trade volume rose by approximately 35%.
• Tourism in Bethlehem doubled compared to previous levels, and tourism in Jericho increased by 50% during the same period.
• Life expectancy in the Palestinian territories was recorded at 73.4 years, ranking 77th globally; this compares to 72.5 years in Jordan, 71.8 years in Turkey, and 80.7 years in Israel.
• Car sales in the West Bank in 2008 were twice those of 2007, indicating a significant rise in consumer purchasing power.
• The International Monetary Fund (IMF) forecasted a 7% economic growth rate for the West Bank in 2009.
• The Bethlehem Small Enterprise Center was inaugurated in early 2008, funded by Germany, with a mission to enhance computer literacy and marketing skills among local entrepreneurs.

• In 2009, efforts to build Palestinian local institutions and governments intensified, with significant contributions from Tony Blair and US General Keith Dayton, aiming to establish viable institutions and promote local peace.

• In August 2009, a state-of-the-art web-based system for tracking goods entering and exiting the West Bank through Palestinian customs was launched in collaboration with the United Nations Conference on Trade and Development (UNCTAD).
• The year 2009 marked the beginning of an economic "boom" in the West Bank, with growth reaching 8%, surpassing growth rates in Israel and Western countries.
• Despite the nominal growth, inflation in 2009 was around 9.9%, resulting in negative real economic growth due to decreased purchasing power.
• Tourism to Bethlehem increased from 1 million visitors in 2008 to nearly 1.5 million in 2009.
• New car imports in 2009 rose by 44%, reflecting increased consumer demand.
• New shopping malls were opened in the cities of Jenin and Nablus, indicating retail sector expansion.
• Following the Palestine Investment Conference, Palestinian developers announced plans to build Rawabi, the first modern Palestinian city.
• In 2010, Ramallah emerged as a central hub of economic activity, attributed to improved security, successful anti-corruption measures, and a large consumer base.
• In 2011, the Palestinian Planning Minister projected GDP growth rates of 9% for 2011, increasing to 10% in 2012 and 12% in 2013.

text:
East Jerusalem was once the business and shopping hub of the West Bank.
However, since the advent of Israeli security checkpoints and the separation
barrier starting over a decade ago, it has become isolated from its customer
base leading to serious economic decline. According to Hanna Siniora of the
Palestinian-American Chamber of Commerce, the turning point was 1993. He
states that since then East Jerusalem has become a closed city through
isolation from the rest of the West Bank causing a loss of 50% of its business
between 1993 and 2001.

According to a 2012 report by the Association for Civil Rights in Israel and
interviews conducted by the Forward, the decline of the economy in East
Jerusalem has led to unprecedented levels of poverty, with 80% of the
Palestinian population living below the poverty line. The main cause is seen
as the political and physical barriers separating it from the rest of the West
Bank. The ACRI report attributing the problem to "'the cumulative effects of
annexation, neglect, rights violations and the completion of the separation
barrier." Another contributing factor to the economic decline is the housing
situation. The Israeli government has facilitated extensive construction for
Israeli settler neighborhoods, but has severely restricted development and
building for the Palestinian population.
openai_summarised_points: • East Jerusalem was historically the primary business and shopping center of the West Bank, serving as a commercial hub for the region.

• The establishment of Israeli security checkpoints and the construction of the separation barrier, beginning over a decade ago, have isolated East Jerusalem from its traditional customer base, resulting in significant economic decline.

• Hanna Siniora, representing the Palestinian-American Chamber of Commerce, identifies 1993 as the critical turning point when East Jerusalem effectively became a closed city due to isolation from the rest of the West Bank.
• Between 1993 and 2001, East Jerusalem experienced a 50% reduction in business activity, directly linked to its increasing isolation.

• A 2012 report by the Association for Civil Rights in Israel (ACRI), supplemented by interviews conducted by the Forward, highlights that the economic downturn in East Jerusalem has precipitated unprecedented poverty levels.
• According to the 2012 ACRI report, approximately 80% of the Palestinian population in East Jerusalem lives below the poverty line.
• The primary cause of this economic and social decline is attributed to political and physical barriers that separate East Jerusalem from the rest of the West Bank.
• The ACRI report specifically cites "the cumulative effects of annexation, neglect, rights violations and the completion of the separation barrier" as key factors exacerbating the economic crisis.

• Another significant factor contributing to the economic decline is the housing situation in East Jerusalem, where the Israeli government has promoted extensive construction for Israeli settler neighborhoods.

• Conversely, the Israeli authorities have imposed severe restrictions on development and building permits for the Palestinian population in East Jerusalem, further limiting economic growth and exacerbating poverty.

text:
Gaza City

According to CIA's _The World Factbook_ , Israel's closure policy, which was
extended when the Hamas administration came to power in 2007, was responsible
for high levels of poverty and unemployment and a significant decline of the
private sector which was heavily reliant upon export markets. Israel blamed
Hamas for taking actions that led to the closure policy. A large part of the
population is dependent on humanitarian assistance, primarily from the UN
agencies.

An easing of Israel's closure policy in 2010 resulted in an improvement in
some economic indicators, but regular exports from the Gaza Strip were still
prohibited. According to the Israeli Defense Forces, the economy improved in
2011, with a drop in unemployment and an increase in GDP. New malls have
opened, local industry is developing and the economic upswing has led to the
construction of hotels and a rise in the import of cars. Wide-scale
development has been made possible by the unhindered movement of goods into
Gaza through the Kerem Shalom Crossing and tunnels between the Gaza Strip and
Egypt. The current rate of trucks entering Gaza through Kerem Shalom is 250
trucks per day. This figure fluctuates depending on the level of interference
with goods being brought into Gaza from Egypt through tunnels. The increase in
building activity has led to a shortage of construction workers. To make up
for the deficit, young people are being sent to learn the trade in Turkey.
openai_summarised_points: • According to the CIA's _The World Factbook_, Israel's closure policy, which was intensified following the Hamas administration's rise to power in 2007, caused high levels of poverty and unemployment in Gaza City and led to a significant decline in the private sector, which had been heavily dependent on export markets.
• Israel attributed the implementation of the closure policy to actions taken by Hamas that it deemed responsible for the restrictions.
• A substantial portion of Gaza City's population relies on humanitarian assistance, primarily provided by United Nations agencies.
• In 2010, an easing of Israel's closure policy resulted in improvements in some economic indicators in Gaza City; however, regular exports from the Gaza Strip remained prohibited.
• According to the Israeli Defense Forces, the Gaza Strip's economy improved in 2011, evidenced by a decrease in unemployment rates and an increase in Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Economic development in 2011 included the opening of new shopping malls, growth in local industry, construction of hotels, and a rise in car imports.
• This wide-scale economic development was facilitated by the unhindered movement of goods into Gaza through the Kerem Shalom Crossing and tunnels connecting the Gaza Strip with Egypt.

• The current rate of trucks entering Gaza through the Kerem Shalom Crossing is approximately 250 trucks per day, though this number fluctuates depending on the level of interference with goods brought in from Egypt via tunnels.
• The surge in construction activity has created a shortage of construction workers in Gaza City.
• To address the deficit in skilled labor, young people from Gaza are being sent to Turkey to receive training in construction trades.

text:
Under the Protocol on Economic Relations, the Palestinians are not allowed to
independently introduce a separate Palestinian currency. Instead, the Israeli
new shekel is the main currency of the Palestinian territories. In the West
Bank the Jordanian dinar is also used. The shekel is used for most
transactions, especially retail, while the dinar is used more for savings and
durable goods transactions. The United States dollar is also sometimes used
for savings and for purchasing foreign goods. The dollar is used by the
overwhelming majority of transactions overseen by the Palestinian Monetary
Authority (that functions as Palestine's central bank), which only represent a
fraction of the transactions conducted in Palestine or by Palestinians.

In the Gaza Strip, the shekel is also the main currency, though it is in short
supply due to the blockade of the Gaza Strip by the PA, Israel and Egypt.

Because the Palestinian Monetary Authority does not issue its own currency, it
is therefore unable to pursue an independent and effective monetary policy. At
the same time, the use of multiple currencies increases the costs and creates
inconvenience arising from fluctuating exchange rates.
openai_summarised_points: • Under the Protocol on Economic Relations, Palestinians are prohibited from independently introducing a separate Palestinian currency.
• The Israeli new shekel serves as the primary currency in the Palestinian territories.
• In the West Bank, the Jordanian dinar is also in circulation alongside the shekel.
• The Israeli new shekel is predominantly used for most transactions, particularly retail purchases.
• The Jordanian dinar is primarily utilized for savings and transactions involving durable goods in the West Bank.
• The United States dollar is occasionally used for savings and for purchasing foreign goods within the Palestinian territories.

• The overwhelming majority of transactions overseen by the Palestinian Monetary Authority, which functions as Palestine's central bank, are conducted in US dollars; however, these transactions represent only a fraction of the total economic activity conducted in Palestine or by Palestinians.
• In the Gaza Strip, the Israeli new shekel is also the main currency, but it is in short supply due to the blockade imposed by the Palestinian Authority, Israel, and Egypt.
• The Palestinian Monetary Authority does not issue its own currency, which prevents it from pursuing an independent and effective monetary policy.
• The use of multiple currencies in the Palestinian territories increases transaction costs and creates inconvenience due to fluctuating exchange rates.

text:
Taxation in the Palestinian territories is a complex system which may involve
payment to the Palestinian Authority (PA) and/or Israel. In 2005, the PA
collected approximately $34 million per month from taxes and other charges,
while Israel collected about $75 million per month in tariffs on foreign
imports and value added taxes (VAT) on Israeli goods and services and on
average retained about $15 million for the payment of water and power bills of
Palestinians, while forwarding the other $60 million to the PA. Israeli
collected funds account for about two-thirds of the PA's self-generated
revenue, which Reuters put at $100 million in December 2012. Since the 2006
Palestinian legislative election and the formation of a Hamas government in
the PA, Israel has regularly withheld the taxes it owes the PA.
openai_summarised_points: • Taxation in the Palestinian territories involves a complex system requiring payments to both the Palestinian Authority (PA) and Israel.
• In 2005, the Palestinian Authority collected approximately $34 million per month from taxes and other charges within the territories.
• During the same period, Israel collected about $75 million per month in tariffs on foreign imports and value added taxes (VAT) on Israeli goods and services consumed by Palestinians.
• Of the $75 million collected by Israel monthly, it retained on average about $15 million to cover the payment of water and power bills for Palestinians.
• The remaining $60 million collected by Israel was forwarded monthly to the Palestinian Authority as part of its revenue.
• Funds collected by Israel on behalf of the PA constitute roughly two-thirds of the PA’s self-generated revenue.
• Reuters reported that the PA’s self-generated revenue was approximately $100 million as of December 2012.

• Since the 2006 Palestinian legislative election and the subsequent formation of a Hamas government within the PA, Israel has regularly withheld the tax revenues it owes to the Palestinian Authority.

text:
According to the Council for European Palestinian Relations, the agricultural
sector formally employs 13.4% of the population and informally employs 90% of
the population. Over the past 10 years, unemployment rates in Palestine have
increased and the agricultural sector became the most impoverished sector in
Palestine. Unemployment rates peaked in 2008 when they reached 41% in Gaza.
openai_summarised_points: • According to the Council for European Palestinian Relations, the agricultural sector formally employs 13.4% of the Palestinian population.
• The agricultural sector informally employs 90% of the Palestinian population, indicating a significant reliance on informal labor within this sector.
• Over the past 10 years, unemployment rates in Palestine have increased, reflecting worsening employment conditions.
• The agricultural sector has become the most impoverished sector in Palestine during this period of rising unemployment.
• Unemployment rates in Palestine peaked in 2008, reaching 41% specifically in the Gaza Strip.

text:
High unemployment in the Palestinian economy led about 100,000 Palestinians to
work in Israel. By March 2014, about 45,000 permits were issued for work in
Israel with further 25,000 issued for work in West Bank settlements. It is
estimated 35,000 Palestinian work through illegal channels and without a
permit. Recently[_when?_] the quota for permits has increased and minimum age
for obtaining one was reduced from 26 to 24. Sectors in which Palestinians are
employed include construction, manufacturing, commerce and agriculture.

As of 2013, average daily wages in Israel and the settlements is nearly 2.2
times higher than in the private sector in the West Bank and over 4 times that
in Gaza. As of 2022, Palestinian monthly minimum wage is ₪1,450, almost a
quarter of the Israeli minimum wage of ₪5,300. In the West Bank, Israeli
labour laws are partially applied through military enactments, and a ruling of
the Supreme Court of Israel of 2007 apply the law for work done inside Israeli
settlements. Yet, there have been incidents where Israeli employers did not
fulfill their legal obligations to the employees by refusing to provide a
paycheck or hide the number of work hours to avoid labour laws such as minimum
wage or social security benefits.

In 2014, an article published on Al-Hayat Al-Jadida, the Palestinian
Authority's official daily, praised Israeli treatment of Palestinian workers.
With having added benefits such as transportation, medical and pensions,
Palestinians are quick to leave their Palestinian employers and work for
Israelis, whenever they have the opportunity to do so. Safety rules are
enforced strictly by Israeli Workers' Union and physical examinations are done
by doctors. The PA has passed labour laws but do not enforce rules such as the
minimum wage, annual vacations, sick leave or extra payments for overtime
work.
openai_summarised_points: • High unemployment in the Palestinian economy has driven approximately 100,000 Palestinians to seek employment in Israel.
• By March 2014, around 45,000 work permits were issued to Palestinians for employment in Israel, with an additional 25,000 permits granted for work in West Bank settlements.
• It is estimated that about 35,000 Palestinians work in Israel through illegal channels without obtaining the necessary permits.
• Recently, the quota for work permits has been increased, and the minimum age required to obtain a permit was lowered from 26 to 24 years old.
• Palestinians employed in Israel and settlements work in various sectors, including construction, manufacturing, commerce, and agriculture.

• As of 2013, the average daily wages for Palestinians working in Israel and Israeli settlements were nearly 2.2 times higher than wages in the private sector in the West Bank and over four times higher than wages in Gaza.
• By 2022, the Palestinian monthly minimum wage was ₪1,450, which is approximately one-quarter of the Israeli minimum wage of ₪5,300.

• In the West Bank, Israeli labor laws are partially applied through military enactments, and a 2007 ruling by the Supreme Court of Israel mandates the application of Israeli labor law for work performed inside Israeli settlements.

• Despite legal protections, there have been instances where Israeli employers failed to meet their legal obligations by refusing to provide paychecks or by concealing actual work hours to circumvent labor laws such as minimum wage requirements and social security benefits.
• In 2014, an article published in Al-Hayat Al-Jadida, the official daily newspaper of the Palestinian Authority, praised the treatment of Palestinian workers by Israelis.

• The article noted that Palestinians receive additional benefits when working for Israelis, such as transportation, medical care, and pensions, making them inclined to leave Palestinian employers for Israeli ones whenever possible.
• Safety regulations for Palestinian workers in Israel are strictly enforced by the Israeli Workers' Union, and medical physical examinations are conducted by doctors.
• Although the Palestinian Authority has enacted labor laws, it does not effectively enforce regulations concerning minimum wage, annual vacations, sick leave, or overtime pay.

text:
